ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I have learned so many things about the deaf and hard-of-hearing culture. I also have learned more ASL than in many other levels 1 language classes.
Sign language, basic signs and how to sign to different people.
After taking this course, I feel that I have learned more ASL than I wouldve have imagined in just one semester.
I learned the basics of American Sign Language and am at a good position to continue deeper learning of the language.
I got an introduction to ASL not only in terms of the actual language but also the culture and ideas surrounding deaf and hard of hearing community. Also exposure to ASL community on campus.
I learned about deaf culture, how to sign basic phrases in ASL, and the different elements of ASL.
This was my first time learning about Deaf culture and sign language, so everything related to this course was new for me.
A comprehensive knowledge of simple signs and an awareness of d/Deaf culture
I learned the basics of ASL communication, the importance of the 5 elements of ASL, and increased my understanding of deaf culture.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think that it was sometimes hard to keep track of all the things we were supposed to be doing outside of classes. I think this class is a lot of fun.
Very interactive, organized. Overall, great class.

I believe that the tests should be online as it is impractical to assume that students can sit in a class and constantly look up to see the professor signing and then try to quickly transcribe what it is that they signed.

I think the strength was the curriculum. I felt like I learned a lot in very little time and it made me actually rather comfortable in deaf spaces. The weakness would probably be the structure of the class in terms of L1 students diving right into a completely deaf space. While I think I learned a lot, it also made me miss vital information for the class.

I really enjoyed this course. Professor Rubin was great, and made the class very enjoyable and a great learning environment. Exams for the class were fair. I learned a lot and will be continuing to L2.
The strength is how many opportunities there are on campus and in New Haven to get involved with Deaf communities. A weakness would be better organization for some of the service projects.
This is an amazing class.

Professor Rubin is an excellent professor, and I learned a lot from her this semester. The only weakness of the course was that it felt repetitive at times, and it was sometimes difficult to balance between the different comfort levels with ASL in the class.

ASL courses at Yale are very unique in terms of teaching structure, as the entire course consists of observing and producing sign language in the classroom. This made every class engaging but also required a lot of focus from each student. I definitely felt like my efforts paid off very quickly, and I felt supported and excited about learning a new language. The "take-home" aspect of the course, the online modules, were somewhat tedious in that they often used signs that we were unfamiliar with, which made it difficult to complete them accurately on the first try. Luckily the workload was relatively light and did not take long to complete each week. The service project component of the course was fascinating but it seemed difficult for ASL 110 students to deeply engage with the projects.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! I love ASL and I cannot wait to continue learning ASL.
yes I would
Yes! I loved ASL. The teacher was amazing and very engaging. Made learning fun.
Yes I would 100% recommend because this is a type of language course that is unique.
Yeah, I believe American Sign Language is a great language to learn and the course made it fun and simple.

I would highly recommend to anyone. The ASL department is very warm and welcoming and regardless of your interest in the language, its a very valuable learning experience that I think anyone will appreciate.
Yes. I enjoyed it. It makes your brain think in a different kind of way. It is surprising how much information you can convey to someone while only knowing a little ASL. I recommend for sure.
Yes! I took a friend to an ASL class during IWDP and to this day he says he wants to take it.

I would recommend this course to anyone who wants to learn ASL or is curious about deaf culture. Additionally, learning ASL is a great way to learn about communication for hearing people too because of the emphasis on facial expressions and communicating with more than just words.

Yes! Taking ASL (despite being finished with my language requirement) is a decision I definitely do not regret. I learned so much, so quickly, about something I had no previous knowledge about, and experienced the classroom in a completely knew way. Also-while this class does meet four times a week, I found myself looking forward to it nearly every day--it was manageable as a 5th course and brought me so much joy this semester.
